speaker: ID
text: basically I just uh looked at what exactly do remotes do .

speaker: ID
text: Uh basically they wait for you to press a key or give a voice command

speaker: ID
text: and then this is translated uh into uh light signals

speaker: ID
text: which are then seen by the T_V_ .

speaker: ID
text: Uh the materials we're gonna need to look at <disfmarker> uh the two big ones are the integrated circuit chip and the battery

speaker: ID
text: and the in integrated circuit chip uh works in conjunction with a a diode transistor or resonator , uh two more resistors and a capacitor

speaker: ID
text: and the battery works in conjunction with a resistor and a capacitor . Um . <vocalsound>

speaker: ID
text: Uh basically what happens is you'll press a number or give a voice command

speaker: ID
text: and this creates a a connection within the the remote

speaker: ID
text: the chip then senses this connection

speaker: ID
text: and produces a signal in a Morse code format .

speaker: ID
text: This signal's sent to the transistor

speaker: ID
text: and then sends it on to the light emitting diode

speaker: ID
text: which is then trai changed into a infrared light

speaker: ID
text: which is sent to the T_V_

speaker: ID
text: and sort of seen by the T_V_

speaker: ID
text: and which uh changes the channels .

speaker: ID
text: as for how we should end up uh using this in our remote uh t couple of main questions are the buttons .

text: and uh raise the production cost .

speaker: ID

speaker: ID
text: and that seems to be the most uh cost-effective way of producing it .

speaker: ID
text: Um also with battery connections the company has some limits on the batteries we can use ,

speaker: ID
text: so I was thinking perhaps a combination of solar cells with a back-up basic battery

speaker: ID
text: and somehow between the combination of that two we might be able to come up with something that uh will last the the lifetime or the five to ten years

speaker: ID
text: and we could still keep that original idea .
